Ok... but, you were talking about tic tac toe

-----Original Message-----
From: Derek James [mailto:blue5432@...] 
Sent: Friday, January 30, 2004 1:33 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [neat] Applying NEAT to Tic-Tac-Toe

--- Chris Christenson <cc57@...> wrote:
> Maybe I am off-base here, but why don't you use a
> neural network to act
> as the evaluation function in conjunction with a
> MinMax.  Therefore,
> outputting one number and forgetting about learning
> how to play the game
> and make legal moves etc.

This works for game domains with a managable branching
factor (e.g., Checkers), where there are a relatively
small number of potential moves on any given turn.

But a MinMax search is not going to work with games
with enormous branching factors (like 19x19 Go, which
has 361 possible moves on the first turn, 360 on the
next, and so on).  

And incidentally, neither in Joseph's project or our
research are we evolving networks that learn to make
legal moves (illegal moves are simply ignored).

Derek
